text: I had no thought of violets of late, The wild, shy kind that spring beneath your feet In wistful April
author: MA

text: days, when lovers mate And wander through the fields in raptures sweet. The thought of violets meant florists’ shops, And
author: MA

text: bows and pins, and perfumed papers fine; And garish lights, and mincing little fops And cabarets and songs, and deadening
author: MA

text: wine. So far from sweet real things my thoughts had strayed, I had forgot wide fields, and clear brown streams;
author: MA

text: The perfect loveliness that God has made,— Wild violets shy and Heaven mounting dreams. And now—unwittingly, you’ve made me dream Of
author: MA

text: violets, and my soul’s forgotten gleam. A Rock, A River, A Tree Hosts to species long since departed, Marked the
author: MA

text: mastodon, The dinosaur, who left dried tokens Of their sojourn here On our planet floor, Any broad alarm of their
author: MA

text: hastening doom Is lost in the gloom of dust and ages. But today, the Rock cries out to us, clearly,
author: MA

text: forcefully, Come, you may stand upon my Back and face your distant destiny, But seek no haven in my shadow,
author: MA

text: I will give you no hiding place down here. You, created only a little lower than The angels, have crouched
author: MA

text: too long in The bruising darkness Have lain too long Facedown in ignorance, Your mouths spilling words Armed for slaughter.
author: MA

text: The Rock cries out to us today, You may stand upon me, But do not hide your face. My river
author: MA

text: was once unseparated. Was Colorado. Red  fast flood. Able to take anything it could wet—in a wild rush— all the
author: MA

text: way to Mexico. Now it is shattered by fifteen dams over one thousand four hundred and fifty miles, pipes and pumps filling
author: MA

text: swimming pools and sprinklers in Los Angeles and Las Vegas. To save our fish, we lifted them from our skeletoned
author: MA

text: river beds, loosed them in our heavens, set them aster — ‘Achii ‘ahan, Mojave salmon, Colorado pikeminnow— Up there they
author: MA

text: glide, gilled with stars. You see them now— god large, gold green sides, moon white belly and breast— making their great speeded way
author: MA

text: across the darkest hours, rippling the sapphired sky water into a galaxy road. The blurred wake they drag as they make
author: MA

text: their path through the night sky is called ‘Achii ‘ahan nyuunye— our words for Milky Way. Coyote too is up
author: MA

text: there, crouched in the moon, after his failed attempt to leap it, fishing net wet and empty, slung over his
author: MA

text: back— a prisoner blue and dreaming of unzipping the salmon’s silked skins with his teeth. O, the weakness of any
author: MA

text: mouth as it gives itself away to the universe of a sweet milk body. Just as my own mouth is dreamed
author: MA

text: to thirst the long desire ways, the hundred thousand light year roads of your throat and thighs. Autumn wind chases in From
author: MA

text: all directions And a thousand chaste leaves Give way. Scatter in me the seeds Of a thousand saplings. Let grow
author: MA

text: a grassy heaven. On my brow: a sun. This bliss is yours, Living World, and alone it endures. Music at
author: MA

text: midnight. Young wine. Lovers hand in hand By daylight, moonlight. Living World, hold me In your mouth, Slip on your
author: MA

text: frivolous shoes And dance with me. My soul Is the wild vine Who alone has grasped it, Who has seen
author: MA

text: through the awful plot, Who will arrive in time to vanquish The river already heavy with blossoms, The moon spilling
author: MA

text: light onto packs Of men. What is sadder than witless Wolves, wind without borders, Nationless birds, small gifts Laden with
author: MA

text: love’s intentions? Fistfuls of rain fall hard, fill My heart with mud. An old wind May still come chasing in.
author: MA

text: Resurrection fire. And me here Laughing like a cloud in trousers, Entreating the earth to bury me. To everything, there
author: MA

text: is a season of parrots. Instead of feathers, we searched the sky for meteors on our last night. Salamanders use
author: MA

text: the stars to find their way home. Who knew they could see that far, fix the tiny beads of their
author: MA

text: eyes on distant arrangements of lights so as to return to wet and wild nests? Our heads tilt up and
author: MA

text: up and we are careful to never look at each other. You were born on a day of peaches splitting
author: MA

text: from so much rain and the slick smell of fresh tar and asphalt pushed over a cracked parking lot. You
author: MA

text: were strong enough—even as a baby—to clutch a fistful of thistle and the sun himself was proud to light up
author: MA

text: your teeth when they first swelled and pushed up from your gums. And this is how I will always remember
author: MA

text: you when we are covered up again: by the pale mica flecks on your shoulders. Some thrown there from your
author: MA

text: own smile. Some from my own teeth. There are not enough jam jars to can this summer sky at night.
author: MA

text: I want to spread those little meteors on a hunk of still warm bread this winter. Any trace left on the
author: MA

text: knife will make a kitchen sink like that evening air the cool night before star showers: so sticky so warm
author: MA

text: so full of light You may write me down in history With your bitter, twisted lies, You may trod me
author: MA

text: in the very dirt But still, like dust, I’ll rise. Does my sassiness upset you? Why are you beset with
author: MA

text: gloom? ’Cause I walk like I’ve got oil wells Pumping in my living room. Just like moons and like suns,
author: MA

text: With the certainty of tides, Just like hopes springing high, Still I’ll rise. Did you want to see me broken?
author: MA

text: Bowed head and lowered eyes? Shoulders falling down like teardrops, Weakened by my soulful cries? Does my haughtiness offend you?
author: MA

text: Don’t you take it awful hard ’Cause I laugh like I’ve got gold mines Diggin’ in my own backyard. You
author: MA

text: may shoot me with your words, You may cut me with your eyes, You may kill me with your hatefulness,
author: MA

text: But still, like air, I’ll rise. Does my sexiness upset you? Does it come as a surprise That I dance
author: MA

text: like I’ve got diamonds At the meeting of my thighs? Out of the huts of history’s shame I rise Up
author: MA

text: from a past that’s rooted in pain I rise I’m a black ocean, leaping and wide, Welling and swelling I
author: MA

text: bear in the tide. Leaving behind nights of terror and fear I rise Into a daybreak that’s wondrously clear I
author: MA

text: rise Bringing the gifts that my ancestors gave, I am the dream and the hope of the slave. I rise
author: MA

text: I rise I rise. Lying, thinking Last night How to find my soul a home Where water is not thirsty
author: MA

text: And bread loaf is not stone I came up with one thing And I don’t believe I’m wrong That nobody,
author: MA

text: But nobody Can make it out here alone. Alone, all alone Nobody, but nobody Can make it out here alone.
author: MA

text: There are some millionaires With money they can’t use Their wives run round like banshees Their children sing the blues
author: MA

text: They’ve got expensive doctors To cure their hearts of stone. But nobody No, nobody Can make it out here alone.
author: MA

text: Alone, all alone Nobody, but nobody Can make it out here alone. Now if you listen closely I'll tell you
author: MA

text: what I know Storm clouds are gathering The wind is gonna blow The race of man is suffering And I
author: MA

text: can hear the moan, 'Cause nobody, But nobody Can make it out here alone. Alone, all alone Nobody, but nobody
author: MA

text: Can make it out here alone. A free bird leaps on the back of the wind and floats downstream till
author: MA

text: the current ends and dips his wing in the orange sun rays and dares to claim the sky. But a
author: MA

text: bird that stalks down his narrow cage can seldom see through his bars of rage his wings are clipped and
author: MA

text: his feet are tied so he opens his throat to sing. The caged bird sings with a fearful trill of
author: MA

text: things unknown but longed for still and his tune is heard on the distant hill for the caged bird sings
author: MA

text: of freedom. The free bird thinks of another breeze and the trade winds soft through the sighing trees and the
author: MA

text: fat worms waiting on a dawn bright lawn and he names the sky his own. But a caged bird stands
author: MA

text: on the grave of dreams his shadow shouts on a nightmare scream his wings are clipped and his feet are
author: MA

text: tied so he opens his throat to sing. The caged bird sings with a fearful trill of things unknown but
author: MA

text: longed for still and his tune is heard on the distant hill for the caged bird sings of freedom.
author: MA
